There are moments in life when a human being witnesses something so beautiful, so transcendent, that words can only stumble in its shadow. For some, it‚Äôs the birth of a child. For others, it‚Äôs a sunrise over the ocean. For me, it is Ewok Hunt in Star Wars Battlefront II. This game mode is not merely a pastime‚Äîit is a revelation, a spiritual awakening disguised as asymmetric multiplayer. It is the purest distillation of fear, wonder, and joy that digital entertainment has ever bestowed upon mortal kind.

The setting alone‚ÄîEndor‚Äôs night, cloaked in darkness, the air thick with mist and mystery‚Äîis enough to stir the soul. You spawn as a stormtrooper, isolated and trembling, flashlight flickering like the last spark of civilization amid the primal wilderness. Somewhere out there, tiny furred gods of the forest‚ÄîEwoks‚Äîwatch with eyes gleaming in the moonlight. You hear the whisper of drums, the rustle of leaves, and then that war horn‚Äîan unholy symphony that makes your heart explode in reverent panic. Every footstep is a prayer; every crunch of a twig, a prophecy of your doom.

And yet, to play as an Ewok is to ascend. No longer are you the hunted‚Äîyou are the spirit of the forest itself, a guardian of nature armed with cunning, courage, and a spear sharp enough to puncture destiny. The balance of power flips, and what once was terror becomes euphoria. You dash between ferns, leap from the shadows, and rain down the will of Endor upon the metallic intruders who dared defile your sacred home. The satisfaction of striking down a stormtrooper and watching his soul vanish into the mist is not mere victory‚Äîit is transcendence.

What makes Ewok Hunt truly divine is its duality. It is both horror and comedy, tension and release. It gives the player something rare in modern gaming: emotion. Not the synthetic excitement of scoreboard triumphs, but a deep, primal experience that binds friends and strangers alike in a ritual of laughter, panic, and awe. The moment when your flashlight dies and your voice cracks over the mic‚Äî‚ÄúWhere is everyone?!‚Äù‚Äîonly to hear giggling from the trees above‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs not gameplay. That‚Äôs communion.

Every match feels like a living myth. You are not just running and hiding or hunting and stabbing‚Äîyou are participating in an ancient story: the clash between technology and nature, arrogance and humility, empire and rebellion. The Ewoks embody the spirit of the underdog, proof that joy and courage can overcome even the most advanced armor. They remind us that power is not measured in blasters or starships, but in heart, cunning, and the strength to fight for one‚Äôs home.

To those who have never played Ewok Hunt, it might seem like a novelty, a silly side mode tacked onto a massive Star Wars shooter. But to those who have felt its heartbeat, who have heard the haunting music swell as fireflies drift through the trees, it is something far greater. It is art. It is poetry written in moonlight and fear. It is the feeling of being alive in a world that wants you to forget how.

Ewok Hunt changed me. It reminded me that beauty often hides in absurdity, that joy can emerge from chaos, and that sometimes the smallest warriors fight the biggest battles. When I close my eyes, I still hear the horns echoing through the forest. They are calling me back‚Äîto the hunt, to the magic, to the sacred firelight of Endor.

And I will always answer.

Be careful of all the positive reviews on this game. Especially the ones that simply talk about the game's specs on paper because despite the numerous amount of glowing reviews on this game there is a harsh reality to any newcomer here.

You either have to be extremely good at the game to conjure any sense of fun.
OR-
Be completely nonchalant and easy going no matter how hard you're being beaten to a pulp (Masochist.)
That or a mega star wars fan.

Look, on the surface when this game functions as intended it's a good game. Barring some balancing and netcode issues. It has fantastic visuals, sound, and attention to detail that still stands up even with modern releases.

But those times are few and far between. You WILL find yourself knee deep with hacker scum, sweaty try-hards, and general issues that end up making your average day on Battlefront 2 mostly on the respawn screen.

Having played this game for over 5 years now I have never gone a single day without at least 1 hacker ruining my experience.

If you are a big star wars fan or are somehow still interested in playing this game please do not pay full price. Either wait for May 4th promos or whenever this game is under 5 bucks. If they do in the future, Epic Games does give this for free too sometimes.

Star Wars Battlefront II has some genuinely fun gameplay. Great combat with large-scale battles, though the scale of battles is not the size that Battlefront 1 had. Just like Battlefront 1, all the fun gameplay came at the end of it's life cycle due to the new content that added new heroes, maps, and new game modes ‚Äî All content that honestly should have been in the game from day one.

The campaign is a major disappointment. The story is one huge letdown with no real replay value, and it never lives up to the potential of its premise that we saw in the trailers.

The biggest issue, though, is the state of multiplayer today. What used to be the best part of the game is now completely unplayable. Hackers have overrun the servers and ruined matches purely to troll, leaving the game effectively dead unless you're willing to put up with constant cheating. EA has abandoned this game, so with no future updates this is the state of play for the foreseeable future.

Overall, it could have been a great Star Wars shooter ‚Äî and for a brief moment, it was ‚Äî but right now it‚Äôs impossible to recommend.

I wanted to like this, but EA‚Äôs reputation and consistent anti-player decisions have driven me away. That being said, there are gameplay issues I consistently run into with finding good servers, and staying with my group. That being said, I‚Äôm choosing not to recommend any EA title, regardless of IP or nostalgia.

Concern Regarding Anti-Cheat Enforcement in Online Play

The overall experience of playing this game online has been severely degraded by a significant and widespread presence of cheating. This issue has a detrimental impact on the core competitive environment and the general enjoyment for legitimate players.

Impact and Vendor Response

The pervasive nature of unauthorized modifications directly ruins the in-game economy (the market) and negatively affects long-term player engagement. What is most concerning is the perceived lack of proactive and decisive action from EA.

A core question remains within the community: What is the demonstrable record of permanent bans issued to confirmed cheaters on the EA network? The current level of enforcement appears ineffective, leading many to doubt the presence of sufficient deterrents.

Demand for Permanent Disincentives

To effectively combat this escalating problem, a fundamental shift in policy is required. I strongly urge EA to adopt a zero-tolerance approach consisting of two mandatory steps:

Permanent User Account Bans: Confirmed cheaters must receive an immediate and permanent ban from the game service.

Game License Revocation: The license associated with the banned account should be permanently revoked.

This measure enforces a vital financial penalty. By requiring permanently banned users to re-purchase the game to attempt to play again, a clear and decisive cost is placed on cheating. Merely relying on kernel-level or client-side anti-cheat software, while useful, is insufficient without the guaranteed, unyielding threat of permanent license removal for repeat or egregious offenses.

Failure to resolve this crisis with immediate and severe enforcement will directly impact my willingness to purchase any future titles from EA.

I was absolutely disappointed with this game. If you want the experience of the original Battlefront 2 - just install and play it, no need to give a chance to this one,

Pros: 
- Good graphics optimization, was able to play in 2K on Ultra with 80-100FPS on a moderate GPU.
- Not bad graphics in general, enjoyed it.
- Never seen any serious bugs.

Cons:
- Campaign is 4-8h long, depending on your style - it was shockingly short for me. It ended exactly at the point, when it felt like it must be a half or 2/3 of it..
- Cards on each unit is just a time-consuming to study feature, that adds nothing to the gameplay.
- Poor single player versatility and epicness - as a fan of the original Battlefront 2, it was absolutely a deal breaker to see, that in Skirmish you can't set up a game with a starship battle, in which you can deploy on the enemie's ship and sabotage it. Can't have a large-scale battle with different vehicles available to jump in. I could continue, but long story short - being able to do less in this game, then in the original Battlefront 2 - is just feeling like I was fooled to buy this game by it's name. My bad, must have checked gameplay videos and reviews prior to purchase.

Be careful of all the positive reviews on this game. Especially the ones that simply talk about the game's specs on paper because despite the numerous amount of glowing reviews on this game there is a harsh reality to any newcomer here.

You either have to be extremely good at the game to conjure any sense of fun.
OR-
Be completely nonchalant and easy going no matter how hard you're being beaten to a pulp (Masochist.)
That or a mega star wars fan.

Look, on the surface when this game functions as intended it's a good game. Barring some balancing and netcode issues. It has fantastic visuals, sound, and attention to detail that still stands up even with modern releases.

But those times are few and far between. You WILL find yourself knee deep with hacker scum, sweaty try-hards, and general issues that end up making your average day on Battlefront 2 mostly on the respawn screen.

Having played this game for over 5 years now I have never gone a single day without at least 1 hacker ruining my experience.

If you are a big star wars fan or are somehow still interested in playing this game please do not pay full price. Either wait for May 4th promos or whenever this game is under 5 bucks. If they do in the future, Epic Games does give this for free too sometimes.
